text:
"text": " Operational Integration of Required 
Time of Arrival with Time-Based 
Management: Concept of Operations 
and Human-in-the-Loop Simulation 
Results Roland Sgorcea
John Timberlake
Steven Osborne
William Symionow
Dr. Gabriele Enea May 2018 MTR180031 MITRE TECHNICAL REPORT Approved for Public Release; Distribution 
Unlimited. Case Number 18-0770 
All rights reserved. McLean, VA Center for Advanced Aviation System Development ii Abstract
This paper presents the concept of operations (ConOps) and the results of a Human-In-The-Loop 
(HITL) simulation for the Time Based Management Required Time of Arrival (TBM-RTA) 
concept. This concept leverages the Required Time of Arrival capability that is available in many 
Flight Management Systems (FMS). Under the TBM-RTA concept, controllers can issue 
equipped aircraft an RTA to a fix, which pilots enter into the FMS. The aircrafts speed is then 
adjusted by the FMS such that it meets the RTA. Additionally, if the RTA time is found to 
exceed the speed envelope of the aircraft, the concept included using a Path Stretch Advisory 
function which allowed controllers to assign an automation-provided Path Stretch solution along 
with an RTA. The Path Stretch maneuver reroutes the aircraft off the current route to a specified 
point, which is represented as a radial and nautical miles distance from the rejoin fix. Results 
from the evaluation showed that the concept is operationally acceptable for pilots and controllers. 
Moreover, RTA-operated flights showed lower cancellation rates and higher delivery accuracy at 
the meter point with smaller speed adjustments when compared to non-RTA flights. Based on 
these results, MITRE believes that the TBM-RTA concept has potential to move operations 
closer to Trajectory-Based Operations (TBO). iii Table of Contents

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is implementing new automation capabilities, which 
leverage investments made by both the FAA and Operators in Performance-Based Navigation 
(PBN) and other flight deck capabilities; this will help transform the National Airspace System 
(NAS) to Trajectory Based Operations (TBO) which is part of the Next Generation Air 
Transportation System (NextGen) program. TBO is an air traffic management (ATM) method for 
strategically planning, managing, and optimizing flights by using time-based management 
(TBM), information exchange between air and ground systems, and the aircrafts ability to fly 
precise paths. Expected benefits of TBO include enhanced flight efficiency, maximized airspace 
and airport throughput, improved operational predictability, and increased operational flexibility. 
The successful operational transition to TBO relies in part on effective TBM, and for some origin-
destination pairs, gate-to-gate TBM. TBM uses time to efficiently integrate traffic demand for 
constrained NAS resources; this goal is accomplished by use of automation to generate a 
schedule at designated points of interest, which consists of flight-specific crossing times to 
achieve the appropriate spacing interval. Effective TBM depends on accurate predictions by 
automation of expected flight crossing times and accurate calculation of a schedule, as well as the 
use of decision support tools (DSTs) by controllers and traffic managers to help meet the 
schedule (e.g., meet time advisories) and modify it as schedule disruptions occur. 
The FAA has deployed numerous PBN procedures and routes throughout the NAS, and airspace 
users have started to realize benefits. However, the full set of PBN benefits will only be realized 
with TBOrequiring full integration between aircraft PBN capability, aircraft flight 
management capabilities, and air traffic strategic planning and TBM. TBM, also referred to as 
metering, is largely provided via the Time-Based Flow Management (TBFM) ground-based 
system which is used to manage traffic to/from several airports today. Additionally, several 
TBFM scheduling enhancements, such as Coupled Scheduling and Extended Metering 
functionality, and new DSTs, that provide automated speed advisories and path change advisories 
for controllers, are in the process of implementation or planned for use across ATC domains [1]. 
These enhancements and tools will help controllers better manage flights to meet the 
desired/scheduled crossing times (i.e., aircraft delivery) at designated points (e.g., metering arcs, 
arrival fixes) along arrival routes and procedures. Moreover, some existing flight-deck 
capabilities can further improve upon the accuracy and efficiency by which those crossing times 
are met. 
The most relevant of these existing flight deck capabilities, present in many aircraft Flight 
Management Systems (FMS), is the capability to accept an ATC-issued Required Time of 
Arrival (RTA) clearance to cross a given point in space at a specified time. The RTA clearance is 
met using real-time aircraft speed adjustments executed by the FMS. One advantage of using the 
FMS to meet the time requirement is that the FMS can better account for wind and flight profile 
uncertainties as compared with ground-based automation advisories. Moreover, the FMS RTA 
capability provides a tightly coupled closed-loop solution, updating its speed automatically to 
adjust for forecast wind errors and unmodeled aircraft dynamics in order to meet the assigned 
RTA. As a result, ATC does not need to frequently issue updated speed assignments to achieve 
flight adjustments required to more accurately meet the metering crossing time target.
Stakeholders have shown strong interest in using RTA-capable flights to achieve near-term TBM 
objectives [9]. The performance and behavior of airborne RTA has been extensively studied in 
simulations and operational trials [2], [3], [4] but not in the context of the FAAs envisioned ii TBO scope. Building on those previous studies, The MITRE Corporations Center for Advanced 
Aviation System Development (MITRE CAASD) performed analyses to develop and refine a 
concept for using RTA to more accurately meet a scheduled crossing time [6]. In this study, 
MITRE simulated use of RTA in the context of a future en route TBM environment (consistent 
with initial TBO) that included TBM scheduling enhancements and DSTs that provided meet-
time advisory options to aid controllers in managing flights to their scheduled crossing times in 
an extended metering operation; the scope included Ground-based Interval Management-Spacing 
(GIM-S) speed advisories [7] (currently available), the Delay Countdown Time (DCT) (currently 
available), and Path Stretch advisories [8] (a future capability). The proposed concept for 
leveraging the aircraft RTA function is referred to in this paper as the TBM-RTA concept. iii Concept of Operations Summary for TBM-RTA2
As indicated in Figure 1, the TBM-RTA concept combines the advanced arrival scheduling 
capabilities provided by the TBFM system and the aircraft FMS RTA function to enable 
improved delivery accuracy of multiple arrival streams to the terminal airspace boundary [1]. 
Currently, controllers issue speed and heading commands to pilots to meet the scheduled flight 
specific crossing times generated by the TBFM system. With the TBM-RTA concept, controllers 
are envisioned as issuing an RTA clearance to the pilot using the TBFM generated Scheduled 
Time of Arrival (STA) value (i.e., flight-specific crossing time) as the basis for the RTA; the 
pilot would input that value into the FMS and the avionics would adjust the aircraft speed to 
cross the designated point at the STA. Figure 1. TBM-RTA Capabilities Overview The TBM-RTA operation is envisioned to be conducted in en route airspace only for meeting 
STAs at the Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) boundary Meter Fix (MF) or a 
Coupled/Extended Meter Point (MP). The TBM-RTA operation begins when an aircraft crosses 
the respective en route TBFM scheduling Freeze Horizon (FH) and the TBFM system assigns an 
STA for a Meter Reference Point (MRP) of interest (which can be a MF or a MP). The relevant 
MRP schedule information is directly available on the situation display for en route controllers 
who issue the arrival procedure to aircraft along with specific instructions for aircraft to meet 
assigned STAs at the associated MRPs. The meet-time advisory options for each flight are 
indicated (and can be accepted or rejected by the controller) both in the MRP list and in the flight 
datablock.
Under the TBM-RTA concept,
